message: Converts to Unix-style line endings I should add..
Try and say what it does to save people spending time deciphering..

I get a lot of files through with Windows line endings. This one leader-based line converts the line endings and resaves the files in one swoop. `nnoremap <leader>F :update<CR>:e ++ff=dos<CR>:setlocal ff=unix<CR>:w<CR>`
specifically using previous string tokens
'set autowrite' ... I use Vim as my primary IDE when hacking source code, and this configures vim to save all open buffers before executing the :make command.
nnoremap <leader>w <C-w>v<C-w>l
that last one was autocompletion
Will make it easier for people to follow I think.
if we get two - imap ;; <C-P>

I'm cheating on this one (it calls a small function), but this line allows me to open a Vertical Split buffer with autocompletion, like :Vbuffer my_other_buffer see: https://github.com/alfredodeza/dotfiles/blob/master/.vimrc#L154
cnoremap %% <C-R>=expand('%:h').'/'<CR> " Expands to the directory of the current file (not your pwd) in command-line mode.
funny - I was just going to say the alias to split the window vertically
set number
to be really explicit- it maps ";;" to autocomplete while in insert mode
@klochner my little function autocompletes buffers though... that is huge for me because I can never completely remember *all* my buffer names :)
@alfredodeza Is there a difference between what your function does and the way :b behaves..?

Part of my transition to vim was taking care of the strong muscle memory habits from textmate, so: " familiar open new line from textmate:
imap <D-Return> <ESC>o
nmap <D-Return> o<ESC>
set no visualbell - good lord that thing is obnoxious.
I have lots of the standard lines (syntax highlighting, a good colorscheme, etc.)
But the one line I *couldn't* live without: inoremap jk <Esc>

That turns "jk" into my escapce character in insert mode. 
Without it, I can barely work with vim.
It's so much nicer than hitting "esc" all the time.

" Directly switch between open splitted windows
map <C-J> <C-W>j
map <C-H> <C-W>h
map <C-L> <C-W>l
map <C-K> <C-W>k
not exactly one line, but close enough :)
set nocompatible
autocmd BufEnter * lcd %:p:h  " Sets path to directory buffer was loaded from
it is useful when you want to have a side by side comparison with another buffer. :b doesn't solve that
@maxcantor well, b opens a buffer in the current window. What Vbuffer does is exactly what :sbuffer does. Except that there is a Vertical Split Window rather than a horizontal one.
map <leader>ew :e <C-R>=expand("%:p:h") . "/" <CR>
open a file from the same directory of the open file, regardless of current directory
:set onelineoff
" oh, and that's a handy timestamp on f8 for journal entries, reads well into spreadsheets too.

if has("autocmd")
  " When editing a file, always jump to the last known cursor position.
  " Don't do it when the position is invalid or when inside an event handler
  " (happens when dropping a file on gvim).
  autocmd BufReadPost *
    \ if line("'\"") > 0 && line("'\"") <= line("$") |
    \   exe "normal g`\"" |
    \ endif
endif " has("autocmd")

" par is a turbo fmt program, I map function keys to un/format current paragraph or line for just about every block of text/code I write!

map <f2> {!}par 1600<CR>
map <F3> {!}par 52<CR>
map <F4> {!}par 66<CR>
map <F5> :.!par 66<CR>
map <F6> :.!par 52<CR>
map <F8> :r !date "+\%D \%r"<cr>$a
@edanm I find that I hit "jk" pretty much constantly in some kind of nervous tic. Looking for an alternative to hitting the Esc key, I did recently purchase some foot pedals...
@brennen I map caps-lock to escape (with http://pqrs.org/macosx/keyremap4macbook/extra.html). Works perfectly for me.
@mtarbit I did that a while ago too. that key should never have been invented

map j gj
map k gk
especially when text wraps
syntax on
@brennen I discovered Ctrl-C also works as Esc in 99% of contexts; works great for me now. Only drawback is that 1%, like how it cancels column insert mode instead of running it.
inoremap jj <ESC>  " Edit my text and move my hands back to home row. 'jj' Boom. Back to normal mode. Mind blown when I first tried it. Off of @stevelosh's .vimrc.
(In those cases I trained myself to use Ctrl-[ which is yet another default escape-a-like mapping.)

allow for switching buffers when a file has changes
set hidden

@atourino By the way, I much prefer "jk" to "jj". At first it was just personal preference (easier for me to hit "jk"), but there is a good reason: I usually hit "jk" all the time out of habit, even when in normal mode. "jk" will cause the cursor to stay in the same place, whereas "jj" will cause it to go up. Try "jk", you might find you like it better too.
@edanm Thanks! I will give it a go for the day and see how it rolls! :D
@edanm Stupid question perhaps, but what do you do when you need to actually type j and k next to each other? Obviously it's rare but I can think of a few cases where you might want to.

@djm When you type 'j' vim just waits a little (~1 second, I don't know exactly) to see if you will be typing the following 'k' to do an Esc. If you do not type the 'k', then it just adds the 'j' into the buffer and then you carry on typing (in this case, typing 'k').

I'm sorry... I'm wrong... the 'j' is added to the buffer when you type it. It will then look for a 'k' (even hinting to it). This time delay won't prevent you from typing so if you type anything other than a 'k', vim will keep typing in the buffer normally. However, if you do wait for the timeout to occur then you can type the 'k' right next to the previously typed 'j'.
@djm And in all the time I've used 'jk', I've never actually had to type "jk"

cause it's mounted over ssh-tunneled samba across the globe, and every operation is takes several seconds.... if it made swap files, it'd take half a minute to open any file! and that with new cachefs!

au!
au BufNewFile,BufRead /dev/www/* setl dir=/var/tmp/vim-dima

Another killer line from my .vimrc: nnoremap <silent> <Space> :nohlsearch<Bar>:echo<CR>

Makes it so "space" turns on search highlighting and turns off any console messages. Since I use search constantly to move around, a quick way to turn off the search higlighting is essential.

@djm atourino and RobLourens are right. Typing "jk" is rare (except when typing out the alphabet!), and unless you're trying to type "jk", then there's no problem. vim does look weird every time you hit "j", but it doesn't actually stop you typing.
@atourino: seriously? does that delay when typing just one "j" not bug the shit out of you?
@jmcantrell I use `jj`, and as @edanm says, you can keep typing after you type j, so it's not an issue for me. Also, why not map window commands to <leader> combos instead of hard-wiring <tab>?
I really hate typing <c-w> for window commands, so: map <tab> <c-w>

The delay when typing a single "j" just really bugs me. <tab> (<c-i>) is natively mapped to a jumplist movement. I find that it works better for my window command leader instead of <c-w> and I just remap something else to the jumplist movement. To me, one single press of <tab> beats <leader>w (or whatever). Think <tab>q for quitting, <tab>h/j/k/l for movement. It's just so much faster than anything else I've tried. See this for more: https://github.com/jmcantrell/dotfiles-vim/blob/master/vimrc#L219

well, this one is actually from my .bashrc, but it's related anyway: https://gist.github.com/855101. it overrides `mvim` so if you give it a directory as the first argument, it will automatically :cd to that directory. then you can do "mvim project/" and use Command-T right away!

@jmcantrell There is no delay to type. You can type whatever you want in that time period. It's just there so that vim can get a chance to determine if you want to type the following 'k' or 'j' (or whatever your Esc mapping is).
@atourino I understand exactly what the (visual) delay is for. It doesn't change my opinion that, in this case, it's annoying. To each his own, I suppose.
@jmcantrell The delay is a little annoying, but since it isn't a real delay but rather a visual thing, I got used to ignoring it pretty quickly. It is a bit annoying though, that's true.
save the file with :W too: cnoreabbrev W w
Enables pathogen with all my bundles! =)
call pathogen#runtime_append_all_bundles()
@edanm I use highlight search all the time, too.  I will definitely have to try that out
@edanm I really like the unhighlight binding, but I use space all the time to advance cursor through line ends and paragraphs in prose, this breaks that, so maybe I'll find another key to do it.....
Quote
Crap. Trying the new iPhone app, and for some reason mistook the text field for a search field.
@muraii ya can delete your posts ya know.... mouse over and x-marks delete
noremap <Leader>m mmHmt:%s/<C-V><cr>//ge<cr>'tzt'm:call EolStyle()<cr>
Removes charcter returns and EolStyle sets the svn:eol-style to native; because too many of my co-workers on windows don't bother setting this up >:0
lol @muraii
shows trailing whitespaces

" Shortcut to rapidly toggle `set list`
nmap <leader>l :set list!<CR>
" Use the same symbols as TextMate for tabstops and EOLs
set listchars=tab:▸\ ,trail:·,eol:¬

@arthurk that's interesting, I like whitespace symbols.... perhaps even for tabs at beginning of line, but it doesn't work here and I'm afraid I don't understand enough to fix in vim... is it gvim only? can you explain more?
@georgalis The listchars setting defines which whitespace characters are displayed, and what they ought to be represented by, the nmap toggles displaying and hiding them, it does work in regular vim
Wow cruft... my .vimrc still starts with:   version 4.0     " avoid warning for wrong version
syn on
set visualbell
^ because that sound is freaking terrible

nnoremap <silent> <Leader>r :set relativenumber<CR>
nnoremap <silent> <Leader>n :set number<CR>
<Leader>n switches back to normal line numbers again.
<Leader>r gives me relative numbers for jumping/yanking/deleting lines.
It's not one line, but the first one needs its companion:

call pathogen#runtime_append_all_bundles

I couldn't live without Pathogen anymore, it makes managing vim plugins so much easier.
@splee Oooh! Great idea. Thanks!
@splee didn't even know about relativenumber before now - might just leave that on!
@odwyerrob Yeah, relativenumber + colorcolumn are my two new favorite lines. Being able to easily see the 80 column mark is priceless for keeping to PEP8.
set wildmode=list:longest,full
^ sane shell-like tab completion

It's actually 2 lines : "set rtp+=~/.vim/vundle.git/"  and "call vundle#rc()"
Vundle (https://github.com/gmarik/vundle) is IMHO one of the best thing that happened to vim since pathogen.
